stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on Course 1’s sky/treetop section art direction (improving the skybox and pivoting the structure into a “birdhouse” theme), adjusts visuals with fog/alpha layering, and prototypes a replacement for an awkward pipe/slide access point using a Yoshi’s Island-style growing flower/vine mechanic. He also discusses a planned public demo (Course 1 only) focused on gathering player feedback about the new physics and camera via a questionnaire, and shares personal updates about stress/mental sharpness and having a newborn.
stream_context.significance_reason: The stream contains concrete release planning for a Course 1 demo (including timeline and structured feedback collection) plus multiple gameplay/level-design commitments: a new slide-speed physics change, removal of 100-coin stars in favor of Yoshi coins, and a major rework of how players reach the sky/slide area via a new flower/vine interaction concept.

findings.summary: Kaze commits to releasing a demo containing only Course 1, explicitly positioning it as a playtest for the project’s new physics and camera rather than as a content showcase.

He plans to ship the demo alongside a structured questionnaire (Google Doc) to collect targeted feedback on camera auto-rotation, pan speed, pitch ranges/default pitch, Mario physics feel, and bug reports.

Kaze outlines a rough release cadence: a video in ~2 weeks, another in ~4–5 weeks, and a demo target around ~8 weeks (ideally 3–4 weeks if possible), tying demo timing directly to his YouTube schedule.

He changes slide physics: vanilla hard-caps speed at 100; his version soft-caps at 95 by asymptotically approaching 95 (~5% per frame) so high-entry speed is preserved while normal sliding still feels familiar.

Course 1’s sky section is being art-directed away from “random color pixels / Minecraft blocks” into a cohesive, Yoshi’s Island-related skybox and a “birdhouse” themed structure (start/end framing idea).

Because players struggled to find the slide entrance, Kaze explores replacing an awkward pipe/route with a clearer Yoshi’s Island reference: a large growable flower/vine that functions as the intended route upward, potentially allowing him to remove signage that was added as a workaround.
Kaze stresses “natural” Mario 64 readability: he wants the level beatable without talking to NPCs, and avoids contrived puzzle logic; hints should be visual/behavioral rather than dialogue-dependent.

He discusses an RPG-like “roleplay” increase for the stage: making it feel more like the player is helping the bunnies (without turning it into heavy quest text), with tutorial bunnies reserved for mechanics useful across the whole game and color-coded.

For the new flower/vine elevator, he plans a continuous upward spiral motion (automatic elevator) and a visual fade-out into fog/sky; he sketches a rendering approach using shade alpha gradients and HUD-style cutout rendering to make the top disappear cleanly.
Kaze confirms a structural collectible change: no 100-coin stars; they’re replaced by Yoshi coins (collect 6) that can be picked up during other missions without losing progress.
findings.quote: There’s no more 100-coin star… I hate 100-coin stars in hacks most of the time.

findings.summary: He notes HD textures do consume ROM space, but gives a concrete example: 16 textures at 0x900 bytes each totals 0x9000 (~36 KB), which he considers manageable.

Tooling pipeline has shifted: he no longer relies on hex-editor model workflows; Fast64 now covers most needs while reducing triangles and enabling higher detail (e.g., gloves/HD textures) without the former pain points.
For debugging hard issues, Kaze uses NEMU because it allows inspection at the assembly level; he mentions a GDB extension exists but he hasn’t set it up.
He’s thinking about accessibility explicitly: aiming for the game to be mostly colorblind-friendly, and also considering deaf players during design/testing (though details are not finalized).

Kaze shares personal strain: he’s been feeling mentally “slower” (basic arithmetic/brain fog), suspects prolonged stress may be affecting cognition, and later ties scheduling difficulty to having a newborn.
findings.quote: If you haven’t noticed, I have a small child. That makes planning things really fucking difficult.

biobak.summary: Biobak pushes visual polish for depth/fog: suggesting duplicated tree layers with adjusted brightness/alpha so treetops fade into fog; Kaze iterates live and agrees when it improves readability.

findings.summary: Lilaa functions as an informal “tooling support” contact during the stream (Kaze calls on her to fix Fast64-related behavior/snapping issues) and is part of the ongoing workflow feedback loop.
ZeroVolt raids the stream; Kaze shares a major life update in response (his daughter was born ~4 weeks prior), anchoring the current dev pace in real-life changes.

key_stories.title: Course 1 demo planned as a physics/camera playtest with a questionnaire
key_stories.summary: Kaze frames the next public demo as a deliberate data-gathering release, not just hype. The plan is to ship Course 1 only, then collect structured feedback (especially on camera autorotation/pan/pitch and physics feel) before locking decisions for the full game.
key_stories.challenge: He needs confidence that players actually like (and can use) the new camera and physics before a full release, and wants feedback that is more actionable than general comments.
key_stories.process: He proposes a demo + Google Doc questionnaire; considers but rejects shipping multiple variant builds due to replay bias and workload; aligns the demo window with upcoming video releases.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete intention and rough timeline emerges (ideal 3–4 weeks; maximum ~2 months), with a defined list of feedback prompts to refine camera/physics.
key_stories.key_quote: I want more data on gameplay. I want more feedback for how people think the physics work and how the camera works.

key_stories.title: Replacing an unclear pipe/slide route with a Yoshi’s Island growing flower/vine
key_stories.summary: Player navigation problems (difficulty finding the slide) drive a redesign: Kaze explores a large, Yoshi’s Island-referential flower bud that grows into a climbable/rideable plant to deliver the player upward. The guiding principle is “natural” readability without relying on NPC dialogue.
key_stories.challenge: The existing route is confusing enough that Kaze added an in-world sign, which he dislikes; the alternative must be intuitive, fun, and not feel like a contrived puzzle in Mario 64.
key_stories.process: He brainstorms interaction language (bud animation, bunny hinting, grab/pull Bowser-style animation, or simpler always-active behavior), prototypes geometry, tests climb annoyance, and pivots toward an automatic upward spiral/elevator behavior with a fade-out at the top.
key_stories.outcome: He tentatively commits to a permanently moving, spiraling plant solution and defers final rendering/alpha-fade implementation to off-stream work.
key_stories.key_quote: That’s kind of the difficulty with Mario 64. When you make stuff like that, you can’t just turn it into puzzles. You have to make it feel really natural.

key_stories.title: New slide-speed soft cap to preserve high entry momentum
key_stories.summary: Kaze modifies a core-feel physics rule: instead of Mario 64’s hard cut at slide speed 100, he introduces a soft cap at 95 so players keep extra speed when entering slides fast. It’s a subtle change aimed at retaining vanilla feel while rewarding skilled movement.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla behavior deletes momentum when entering a slide above the cap, which can feel bad in a movement-focused hack with new physics.
key_stories.process: He implements an asymptotic decay toward 95 (about 5% per frame when above the cap) rather than an immediate clamp.
key_stories.outcome: Sliding “should feel the same” in normal play but preserve speed for fast entries, improving flow and mastery.
key_stories.key_quote: If you jump on a slide with more than 100 speed, you instantly lose all of it… I soft capped it at 95.

open_questions.topic: How the demo feedback will concretely change camera/physics defaults
open_questions.context: Kaze plans a questionnaire-driven demo to validate autorotate, pan speed, pitch defaults/range, and Mario physics feel, but the decision rules for interpreting feedback aren’t defined on-stream.
questions: What specific feedback thresholds would make you change the camera defaults versus keeping them and improving tutorialization?
How will you separate “players dislike it” from “players didn’t understand it” when reading questionnaire responses?
Will you publish a summary of findings and a changelog post-demo to show players how their feedback influenced the build?

open_questions.topic: Final interaction language for the growing flower/vine mechanic
open_questions.context: Kaze wants a Yoshi’s Island-style bud/flower route that remains intuitive without NPC dialogue, and he debates between a pull interaction, an always-active elevator, or other hints (animation, sound cues, bunny behavior).
questions: What is the simplest version of the mechanic you’d ship if you had to lock it for the demo tomorrow?
How will you teach “grab/pull” (if used) purely through animation and level context without forcing bunny dialogue?
Where else (overworld or later courses) do you imagine reusing this mechanic so it feels like a consistent vocabulary rather than a one-off?

open_questions.topic: Accessibility testing plan (colorblind and deaf players)
open_questions.context: Kaze says the game is being made “mostly colorblind friendly” and mentions considering deaf players, but no concrete testing pipeline or constraints are stated.
questions: What specific accessibility issues have you already encountered in Course 1 that made you bring up colorblind/deaf players here?
Do you have a plan to recruit testers (or use simulators) before the demo to catch readability problems early?
Which game systems will carry the most accessibility weight: UI, sound cues, NPC hints, or level color/value contrast?

open_questions.topic: How parenthood and stress are reshaping development practices
open_questions.context: Kaze links planning difficulty and bonus-stream uncertainty to having a newborn, and also describes recent brain fog that he attributes to stress or aging.
questions: How has having a newborn changed your day-to-day workflow (when you code, how long you can focus, what tasks you avoid)?
Have you changed scope, deadlines, or team delegation because of the new constraints?
When you notice the ‘brain feels stupid’ moments, what do you do to keep development safe (fewer risky refactors, more testing, more breaks)?
